subsection.title: Determining the form indirectly
subsection.p:
Here we will carry out the indirect analysis method described in
for a matrix A that is similar to a triangular-block nilpotent form matrix N as in .

example.p: Suppose A is an 18 \times 18 matrix that is similar to the triangular-block nilpotent matrix N = \begin{bmatrix} N_1 \\ \amp N_2 \\ \amp\amp N_3 \\ \amp\amp\amp N_4 \\ \amp\amp\amp\amp N_5 \end{bmatrix} , where the elementary nilpotent blocks N_1 and N_2 are each 5 \times 5, blocks N_3 and N_4 are each 3 \times 3, and block N_5 is 2 \times 2.
We will carry out our analysis as if we don't actually know the form matrix N, but at the same time we will use our secret knowledge of N to know the required properties of A.

We should first compute the powers of A to determine the degree of nilpotency. For this matrix, we should find A^5 = \zerovec while A^4 \neq \zerovec. This would tells us that the largest block in N is size 5 \times 5 (which we know it is). After this we should compute \rank A^4, and in this case we should find it to be 2, which would tells us that there are two blocks of size 5 \times 5.

After determining the size and number of blocks of largest size, we would continue with rank computations of lower power. For this matrix, we would calculate \rank A^3 = 4. Since we already know there are two blocks of size 5 \times 5, and each of these blocks should increase in rank by one from A^4 to A^3, we would expect \rank A^3 = 4, which tells us that there are no blocks of size 4 \times 4.

However, calculating \rank A^2 = 8 yields a rank larger than expected. The two 5 \times 5 blocks should only increase the rank from 4 to 6 as we move from A^3 to A^2, but the calculated rank is 2 larger than expected. This means that two new blocks have appeared, and since they appeared at the second power, they must have size 3 \times 3. So know we know about two 5 \times 5 blocks and two 3 \times 3 blocks.

Finally, with four known blocks, we would expect the rank to increase from 8 to 12 as we move from A^2 to A^1. But a calculation should reveal \rank A = 13, which means that one new block has appeared. And since it appeared at exponent one, it must have size 2 \times 2.

From above, we have \rank A = 13, so \nullity A = 18 - 13 = 5. This means that N should have five blocks (which we know it does). And since we already have 5 blocks (two 5 \times 5 blocks, two 3 \times 3 blocks, and one 2 \times 2 block), we have enough information to know the form matrix N precisely.

remark.p: At \rank A, there is no further backwards one can go. But what if our number of blocks hasn't reached \nullity A? A 1 \times 1 elementary nilpotent block is just a 1 \times 1 zero matrix, and makes no contribution to the rank at any exponent. So if we haven't yet filled out the full size of the matrix at the end of the analysis, we would conclude that the rest of the form matrix is filled out by 1 \times 1 zero blocks.

subsection.title: Determining a transition matrix
subsection.p: Here are two examples of determining a transition matrix P that will put a nilpotent matrix A into triangular-block nilpotent form. In the first we will carrying out , but in the second we will use a different strategy.

example.title: A 5 \times 5 example
example.p:
Consider the 5 \times 5 matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 1 \amp -2 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp -2 \amp -2 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp -3 \amp -2 \amp -1 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] . Compute the powers of A:
A^2 \amp= \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \amp A^3 \amp= \zerovec . So A is nilpotent of degree 3.

The standard basis for \R^5 has five vectors in it, so we begin with five A-cyclic spaces:
W_1 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_1, A\uvec{e}_1, A^2\uvec{e}_1, \dotsc \}, \quad W_2 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_2, A\uvec{e}_2, A^2\uvec{e}_2, \dotsc \},
W_3 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_3, A\uvec{e}_3, A^2\uvec{e}_3, \dotsc \}, \quad W_4 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_4, A\uvec{e}_4, A^2\uvec{e}_4, \dotsc \},
W_5 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_5, A\uvec{e}_5, A^2\uvec{e}_5, \dotsc \}.
But recall that for any matrix B, the product B \uvec{e}_j is precisely the \nth[j] column of B. So, by examining when the columns of powers of A first become zero, we see we can reduce the cyclic spanning sets for each of these spaces:
W_1 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_1, A\uvec{e}_1, A^2\uvec{e}_1 \}, \quad W_2 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_2, A\uvec{e}_2, A^2\uvec{e}_2 \},
W_3 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_3, A\uvec{e}_3, A^2\uvec{e}_3 \}, \quad W_4 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_4, A\uvec{e}_4 \},
W_5 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_5, A\uvec{e}_5, A^2\uvec{e}_5 \}.

We don't have any dimension 1 cyclic spaces, so let's move on to considering the collection of final vectors from each basis: \{ A^2\uvec{e}_1, A^2\uvec{e}_2, A^2\uvec{e}_3, A\uvec{e}_4, A^2\uvec{e}_5 \}. Examining the columns of A^2, notice that the first three vectors are all equal to each other, and the fifth vector is the negative of the those first three. Let's begin with the dependence relation A^2\uvec{e}_1 - A^2\uvec{e}_2 = \zerovec . Factoring out the A^2, this turns into A^2(\uvec{e}_1 - \uvec{e}_2) = \zerovec.

aside.title: Careful
aside.p: It is not correct to just cancel off the A^2, since A^2 is not invertible.

example.p:
We form the new cyclic space generated by \uvec{f}_1 = \uvec{e}_1 - \uvec{e}_2, and call it U_1. The above relation says that A^2 \uvec{f}_1 = \zerovec, so we have U_1 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_1, A \uvec{f}_1 \} . Our dependence relation involved the final vectors from W_1 and W_2. These two spaces have equal dimension, so we can use the new space U_1 to replace either of W_1 or W_2. If we decide to replace W_1, our new collection of cyclic subspaces is
U_1 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_1, A\uvec{f}_1 \}, \quad W_2 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_2, A\uvec{e}_2, A^2\uvec{e}_2 \},
W_3 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_3, A\uvec{e}_3, A^2\uvec{e}_3 \}, \quad W_4 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_4, A\uvec{e}_4 \},
W_5 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_5, A\uvec{e}_5, A^2\uvec{e}_5 \}.
We will work more quickly through this process now.
From the dependence relation A^2\uvec{e}_2 - A^2\uvec{e}_3 = \zerovec obtain new cyclic vector \uvec{f}_2 = \uvec{e}_2 - \uvec{e}_3, and use it to replace W_2:
U_1 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_1, A\uvec{f}_1 \}, \quad U_2 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_2, A\uvec{f}_2 \}, \quad W_3 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_3, A\uvec{e}_3, A^2\uvec{e}_3 \},
W_4 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_4, A\uvec{e}_4 \}, \quad W_5 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_5, A\uvec{e}_5, A^2\uvec{e}_5 \}.
From the dependence relation A^2\uvec{e}_3 + A^2\uvec{e}_5 = \zerovec obtain new cyclic vector \uvec{f}_3 = \uvec{e}_3 + \uvec{e}_5, and use it to replace W_3:
U_1 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_1, A\uvec{f}_1 \}, \quad U_2 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_2, A\uvec{f}_2 \}, \quad U_3 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_3, A\uvec{f}_3 \},
W_4 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_4, A\uvec{e}_4 \}, \quad W_5 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_5, A\uvec{e}_5, A^2\uvec{e}_5 \}.
From the dependence relation A\uvec{f}_2 - A\uvec{e}_4 = \zerovec obtain new cyclic vector \uvec{f}_4 = \uvec{f}_2 - \uvec{e}_4, and use it to replace U_2. However, \uvec{f}_4 only generates a cyclic space of dimension 1, and is the negative of A^2 \uvec{e}_5. So discard \uvec{f}_4, bringing us down to four cyclic spaces:
U_1 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_1, A\uvec{f}_1 \}, \quad U_3 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_3, A\uvec{f}_3 \},
W_4 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_4, A\uvec{e}_4 \}, \quad W_5 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_5, A\uvec{e}_5, A^2\uvec{e}_5 \}.
From the dependence relation A \uvec{f}_1 + A \uvec{f}_3 + 2 A \uvec{e}_4 = \zerovec obtain new cyclic vector \uvec{f}_5 = \uvec{f}_1 + \uvec{f}_3 + 2 \uvec{e}_4 , and use it to replace U_1. However, \uvec{f}_5 only generates a cyclic space of dimension 1, and is equal to A^2 \uvec{e}_5 - A \uvec{e}_4 . So discard \uvec{f}_5, bringing us down to three cyclic spaces:
U_3 = \Span \{ \uvec{f}_3, A\uvec{f}_3 \}, \quad W_4 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_4, A\uvec{e}_4 \}, \quad W_5 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_5, A\uvec{e}_5, A^2\uvec{e}_5 \}.
From the dependence relation A \uvec{f}_3 - A \uvec{e}_4 - A^2 \uvec{e}_5 = \zerovec obtain new cyclic vector \uvec{f}_6 = \uvec{f}_3 - \uvec{e}_4 - A \uvec{e}_5 , and use it to replace U_3. However, \uvec{f}_6 only generates a cyclic space of dimension 1, and is equal to A^2 \uvec{e}_5 . So discard \uvec{f}_5, bringing us down to two cyclic spaces:
W_4 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_4, A\uvec{e}_4 \}, \quad W_5 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_5, A\uvec{e}_5, A^2\uvec{e}_5 \}.
Since A does not have maximum degree of nilpotency, we know it is not similar to an elementary nilpotent form matrix. In other words, it is not possible for us to reduce down to a single A-invariant space, and the fact that A \uvec{e}_4 and A^2 \uvec{e}_5 are independent confirm that we are finished at this point. All that is left is to form the transition matrix
P = \begin{bmatrix} | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \\ \uvec{e}_5 \amp A \uvec{e}_5 \amp A^2 \uvec{e}_5 \amp \uvec{e}_4 \amp A \uvec{e}_4 \\ | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \end{bmatrix} = \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -2 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \end{array}\right] , where we have ordered the bases for our A-cyclic spaces in the columns of P according to their dimensions to ensure that the elementary nilpotent blocks appear in order of decreasing size in the form matrix \inv{P} A P:
\inv{P}AP = \begin{bmatrix} \boxed{ \begin{matrix} 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{matrix} } \\ \amp \boxed{ \begin{matrix} 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \end{matrix} } \end{bmatrix} .

remark.p: Once again, it is not necessary to compute \inv{P} to know the form of \inv{P}A P in . We know that each block is elementary nilpotent, and the number and sizes of the blocks is determined by the number and dimensions of the obtained A-cyclic spaces.

example.title: A 9 \times 9 example
example.p:
Consider the matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrrrrr} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -5 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -5 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -5 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] . With such a large matrix, would take quite a while. Instead, we'll try arrive at the transition matrix P a bit faster by using the observation that the final vectors in each of a complete set of independent, cyclic bases for nilpotent A must form a linearly independent set in the null space of A.

But first, let's use the patterns of to determine the number and sizes of the blocks in the triangular-block nilpotent form for A, as this will tell us the number and dimensions of A-cyclic spaces that we need. Ask your favourite computer algebra system (CAS) to compute the powers of A. This will confirm that A is nilpotent, with degree of nilpotency 4. This tells us that the largest block in the nilpotent triangular form for A should have size 4 \times 4. Now ask your CAS to compute \rank A it should return the answer 5. Therefore, \nullity A = 9 - 5 = 4, so we are looking for four blocks in total. Next, have your CAS tell you that \rank(A^3) = 1, and conclude that there is only a single block of size 4 \times 4. Computing \rank (A^2) = 2 and combining it with the previously calculated \rank A = 5, we can conclude that there are also two 2 \times 2 blocks. But as this is only three of the four blocks accounted for, we must also have a final 1 \times 1 zero block. So we now know exactly what we're looking for: four independent, cyclic subspaces of dimensions 4,2,2,1.

The first column of A^3 is nonzero and lies in the null space of A (since A^4 = \zerovec), so we can get our desired four-dimensional cyclic subspace by taking W_1 = \Span \{ \uvec{e}_1, A\uvec{e}_1, A^2 \uvec{e}_1, A^3 \uvec{e}_1 \}.

We could try to use a similar approach to get a dimension 2 cyclic space by examining the zero columns in A^2, but unfortunately there are none. So let's attack more directly using the null space of A, since we will need the final vectors from each of our cyclic bases to form an independent set in this null space.

Ask your CAS to put A into RREF. From \RREF(A), we find the null space of A to be
\Span \left\{ \left[ \begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{array} \right], \left[ \begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 0 \\ -2 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{array} \right], \left[ \begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 5 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right], \left[ \begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -2 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] \right\}.
Write \uvec{n}_1,\uvec{n}_2,\uvec{n}_3,\uvec{n}_4 for these four null space basis vectors above. Now, \uvec{n}_1 lies in W_1 (it's a scalar multiple of A^3 \uvec{e}_1), so let's move on to considering \uvec{n}_2. Since A\uvec{n}_2 = \zerovec, the vector \uvec{n}_2 generates a one-dimensional cyclic space. Could we enlarge it to a two-dimensional cyclic space? This would entail going backwards in the cyclic spanning set sequence \{ \uvec{v}, A \uvec{v}, A^2 \uvec{v}, \dotsc \} , where each vector is A times the previous one. We already have the last-before-\zerovec in this sequence as \uvec{n}_2. So, we would like to determine a vector \uvec{n}_2' such that A\uvec{n}_2' = \uvec{n}_2. This is equivalent to trying to find a solution to the system \left[\begin{array}{c|c} A \amp \uvec{n}_2 \end{array}\right] . Ask your CAS to put the augmented matrix above into RREF you will discover that this system is inconsistent. This is not a failure though, because we know we need a one-dimensional cyclic space that is independent from W_1, and the space W_4 = \Span \{ \uvec{n}_2 \} fits the bill.

aside.title: Note
aside.p: We have labelled this one-dimensional space as W_4 instead of W_2 because we know we want four cyclic spaces ordered from largest to smallest, and the one-dimensional space will have to be the smallest.

example.p: Let's try the same idea for \uvec{n}_3. Since A\uvec{n}_3 = \zerovec, the vector \uvec{n}_3 generates a one-dimensional cyclic space. Could we enlarge this space by finding \uvec{n}_3' such that A\uvec{n}_3' = \uvec{n}_3? To do this, try to solve the system \left[\begin{array}{c|c} A \amp \uvec{n}_3 \end{array}\right] . This time the system has solutions, and a particular solution is \uvec{n}_3' = (-5, 0, 10, 0, -5, 0, 6, 0, 0) . Using this vector we can form a two-dimensional cyclic space W_2 = \Span \{\uvec{n}_3', A\uvec{n}_3' \} , where A\uvec{n}_3'=\uvec{n}_3.

aside.title: Note
aside.p: If we hadn't pre-determined the number and dimensions of the required cyclic spaces, we might be tempted to try to enlarge this space even further by going backwards another step. But system \left[\begin{array}{c|c} A \amp \uvec{n}_3' \end{array}\right] is inconsistent anyway.

example.p: We just need one more two-dimensional cyclic space. Let's work with \uvec{n}_4 now. The system \left[\begin{array}{c|c} A \amp \uvec{n}_4 \end{array}\right] is also consistent, and one particular solution is \uvec{n}_4' = (2, 0, -4, 0, 3, 0, -2, 0, 0) , giving us our needed cyclic space W_3 = \Span \{ \uvec{n}_4', A\uvec{n}_4' \} = \Span \{ \uvec{n}_4', \uvec{n}_4 \} .

We now have the required collection of A-cyclic subspaces of \R^9. Use their cyclic bases to form the matrix P, to get
P \amp = \begin{bmatrix} | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \\ \uvec{e}_1 \amp A\uvec{e}_1 \amp A^2\uvec{e}_1 \amp A^3\uvec{e}_1 \amp \uvec{n}_3' \amp A\uvec{n}_3' \amp \uvec{n}_4' \amp A\uvec{n}_4' \amp \uvec{n}_2 \\ | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \end{bmatrix}
\amp = \left[ \begin{array}{rrrrrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -10 \amp 0 \amp -5 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp -10 \amp 0 \amp 5 \amp 0 \amp-2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -10 \amp 0 \amp 10 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -10 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -5 \amp 0 \amp 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 6 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -10 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array} \right]
. If we wanted to ensure that this transition matrix is in fact invertible, we could compute its rank to be 9. But actually, we will see in that if the collection of terminal null space vectors from each cyclic basis is a linearly independent set, then the cyclic subspaces must form an independent collection.
